column6: There is an index and experimental fishery in Unit 1 and a commercial fishery in Unit 2.
column19: The stocks correspond to S. mentella in Unit 1 and 2, and S. fasciatus in Unit 1 and 2 (2 management units). Each stock have a single LRP for both Units.
column20: They are sharing the same genetic background.
column64: Unit 2 is co-managed with France (Saint-Pierre et Miquelon)
column67: Reference points were developped for both redfish stocks: S. mentella in Units 1 and 2, and S. fasciatus in Units 1 and 2. USR is defined as 80% of Bref. They correspond to 297 kt for S. mentella and 263 kt for S. fasciatus.
column71: Reference points were developped for both redfish stocks: S. mentella in Units 1 and 2, and S. fasciatus in Units 1 and 2. LRP is defined as 40% of Bref. They correspond to 148 kt for S. mentella and 132 kt for S. fasciatus.
column75: Mortality rates were computed within the operating models of the MSE and will be reported online when the Research document will be published. Natural mortality rates (M) for base case OMs have been set at 0.1 yr-1 for S. mentella and 0.125 yr-1 for S. fasciatus.
column77:
According to research survey in Unit 1 in 2017, total minimum trawlable biomass was estimated to be 2,166,000 t for S. mentella, the highest value observed since 1984. Total biomass of S. fasciatus estimated to be 346,000 t is of the same order of magnitude as the highest value observed since 1984.
In Unit 2 in 2016, minimum trawlable biomass of Redfish greater than 22 cm was estimated to be 86,000 t for S. mentella and 167,000 t for S. fasciatus. 
SAR 2018/032: http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/csas-sccs/Publications/SAR-AS/2018/2018_032-eng.html
column82: In 2017, based on the MSE, S. mentella was in the Healthy Zone and S. fasciatus in the Cautious Zone. SAR 2018/033: http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/csas-sccs/Publications/SAR-AS/2018/2018_033-eng.html

column91:
Excerpt from the scientific opinion to be published:
[...]

column92: Have been developed and implemented, but not evaluated
column93:
IFMP: publication in progress.

Excerpt from the next scientific opinion to be published (EVALUATION OF CRABE STOCKS FROM THE SNOW OF THE ESTUARY AND NORTHERN GULF OF THE SAINT-LAURENT (ZONES 13 to 17, 12A, 12B, 12C and 16A) IN 2018) :

Perspectives for each area include three possible scenarios for setting the 2019 TAC. These are established taking into account the value and uncertainty of a combined indicator (consisting of the commercial catch per unit of effort (CPUE) and the number per unit of effort (NUE) of the post-season scientific survey) and related indicators (crab shell size and condition, expected recruitment) of the stock status, with the objective of sustainable resource management. The characteristics of each scenario are as follows:
1) Upper Scenario
- higher probability of higher operating intensity for the upcoming season 
- level of harvesting that may result in fishing mortality above the historical average 
- sampling pressure that may not be sustainable in the long term and, 
- likely decrease in abundance compared to the previous year if recruitment is relatively stable or decreasing
2) Intermediate scenario
- probability that the operating intensity will be moderate for the coming season, similar to the previous season 
- assumed harvest level to maintain fishing mortality close to the historical average
- could maintain the stock at a level of abundance similar to the previous year 
3) Lower scenario
- higher probability that the exploitation intensity will be lower for the upcoming fishing season than the previous one
- assumed conservative harvest level resulting in fishing mortality below the historical average 
- could lead to an increase in stock abundance over the previous year or to the maintenance of existing biomass over a longer period of time.

column79:
The answer is motivated both by the cyclical nature of the resource, which is in a downward phase in 2018, and the lack of a precautionary approach. The precautionary approach is being developed with an implementation target for 2020-2021.
It should be noted that the absence of a post-season survey in 2017 and 2018 has greatly increased uncertainty.

column91:
Extract from the next scientific opinion to be published (ESTUARY AND NORTHERN GULF OF THE SAINT-LAURENT (ZONES 13 to 17, 12A, 12B, 12C and 16A) IN 2018):

Prospects : 
- A 3rd decline in the combined indicator in a context where recruitment to the fishery is expected to remain low in the short term suggests that the TAC should be reduced in 2019.
1) Upper Scenario: A 25% decrease in the TAC from 2018.
2) Intermediate scenario: more than 30% of the TAC compared to 2018.

column93:
IFMP: publication in progress.
Excerpt from the next scientific opinion to be published (EVALUATION OF CRABE STOCKS FROM THE SNOW OF THE ESTUARY AND NORTHERN GULF OF THE SAINT-LAURENT (ZONES 13 to 17, 12A, 12B, 12C and 16A) IN 2018) :

Perspectives for each area include three possible scenarios for setting the 2019 TAC. These are established taking into account the value and uncertainty of a combined indicator (consisting of the commercial catch per unit of effort (CPUE) and the number per unit of effort (NUE) of the post-season scientific survey) and related indicators (crab shell size and condition, expected recruitment) of the stock status, with the objective of sustainable resource management. The characteristics of each scenario are as follows:
1) Upper Scenario
- higher probability of higher operating intensity for the upcoming season 
- level of harvesting that may result in fishing mortality above the historical average 
- sampling pressure that may not be sustainable in the long term and, 
- likely decrease in abundance compared to the previous year if recruitment is relatively stable or decreasing
2) Intermediate scenario
- probability that the operating intensity will be moderate for the coming season, similar to the previous season 
- assumed harvest level to maintain fishing mortality close to the historical average
- could maintain the stock at a level of abundance similar to the previous year 
3) Lower scenario
- higher probability that the exploitation intensity will be lower for the upcoming fishing season than the previous one
- assumed conservative harvest level resulting in fishing mortality below the historical average 
- could lead to an increase in stock abundance over the previous year or to the maintenance of existing biomass over a longer period of time.
